Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation2: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Story: Tonight is the only evening I have free with Mia before I leave for a week-long conference. She’s been looking forward to this—she even made reservations at our favorite restaurant. I can see the excitement in her eyes, and I know how much it means to her that we spend this time together. But as I’m getting ready, my phone buzzes: the clerk has just delivered a case file to my chambers. It’s for a procedural hearing in two weeks, nothing complicated, but the chief judge expects us to be meticulous, to never let anything slip through the cracks. I know I should at least skim the file tonight, get a sense of the issues, so I’m not caught off guard later. The weight of both expectations presses on me—Mia’s hope for a perfect evening, the court’s demand for diligence. I stand in the hallway, keys in hand, torn between the warmth of her waiting smile and the cold stack of papers on my desk, feeling the tension coil tighter inside me with every passing minute.
